TUTORIAL.TITLE: Password-protected sites
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: How to specify a username and password in the Project Properties or enter them into the URL

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Downloading password-protected Web sites.

There are two kinds of password-protected Web sites. One type asks for a username and password in a standard Windows-type dialog (BASIC and NTLM authentication,) while the other type requires you to logon directly on a Web page.

Web sites that require BASIC and NTLM-authentication.

To download this type of site, either specify the username and password in the Project Properties dialog | Advanced | Password section, or type them directly in the URL, such as: http://username:password@www.server.com/...

Notice that a colon separates the password from the username and the @ symbol separates them from the server name.

Some sites use NTLM authentication, which looks like the above, but with a third box labeled "DOMAIN" along with the username and password. Enter the domain name along with the username in the same field in the Project Properties dialog | Passwords this way:

DOMAIN\username

The backslash symbol separates the domain name from the username. When you are done with the Project Properties changes, click the OK button to save them.

NTLM authentication is supported only in the Pro and Enterprise editions of Offline Explorer.

Authentication in a Web form.

It is easy to download this type of site.

You need to browse to the logon page of the site using the internal Browser of %OENAME%.

If you need to download the site immediately and only once, you can proceed with the logon and begin downloading the desired pages using %OENAME%. The program will use the session cookies of the logged on site from the internal browser.

You can also record the logon form contents in a Project, so that %OENAME% will know how to log itself on whenever you wish to download the site. This is useful when you want to schedule the site download or perform it later, or if you want to update the downloaded site in the future.

Once you have entered your username and password on the logon page in the internal browser, press and hold the Alt + Ctrl keys on your keyboard, click the Logon (or Submit) button in the Web form and release the keyboard buttons. You should get a new Project that contains the Web form information recorded in the URL field.

Adjust the Project settings as you wish (set the Level and other parameters) and click the OK button to save the Project. You may begin downloading at any time.

It is also recommended to make sure that the "Use alternate connection method" box is checked in the Internet tab of the Ribbon.

The form recording method is supported only in the Pro and Enterprise editions of Offline Explorer.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Streaming Audio or Video
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: You can download a RealPlayer or MS Media Player streaming file to your hard disk for later viewing

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Downloading Video and Audio streams to your hard disk.

Without %OENAME%, you can only play MS Media Player and Real Player clips online. You cannot save them for later viewing and must stream it from the Internet again if you wish to view it again.

Also, if you have a slow or unreliable Internet connection, watching video clips online involves low quality or unstable sound and picture.

Overcome these limitations!

Offline Explorer Pro and Enterprise editions overcomes these problems by downloading the desired streams to your hard disk so you can play them as often as you like, even without any Internet connection.

Since video files may disappear from Web sites or be replaced with other files, downloading them will help you to build your own media library.

It is even possible to load the highest-quality videos on any kind of connection, including via modem. Of course, this will take more time than on a high-speed DSL, but the video quality will be preserved and you will enjoy it without distortions.

All this is possible because Offline Explorer Pro and Enterprise support streaming protocols - RTSP (for RealPlayer streams) and MMS (for MS Media Player streams.)

How to download media streams.

You can add a link to %OENAME% that begins with the rtsp:// or mms:// prefix and download it.

You can also have %OENAME% download a Web page with links to media files and the program will load the desired streams automatically.

It is recommended that you set the Level setting to 1 or more depending on the Web site layout, and change the Location boxes of the Project Properties | File Filters | Audio and Video sections to "Load from any site." This is necessary because often streaming media files are located on other Web sites.

Do not forget to click OK button to save changes when you finish editing Project Properties.

Selecting the desired stream bandwidth.

Some audio and video streams may contain several versions of different quality in the same URL.

You can select which version you want to download using the Maximum RTSP bandwidth setting in the Options dialog | Speed section.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Web Form submission results
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Loading search engine sites, quiz results, etc.

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Recording Web form contents and downloading submission results.

There are various Web forms used on the Internet. Some of them help you to search Web sites, some are for logon protected site areas and others perform navigation or answer questions.

Offline Explorer Pro and Enterprise editions can record any Web form parameters and save them as a Project.

Browse to the page with the desired Web form in %OENAME% internal browser, fill in the form fields, then press and hold down Alt + Ctrl keys on your keyboard, click the Submit button in the Web form and release the keyboard buttons. You will see a new Project that contains the Web form information recorded in the URL field.

Adust the Project settings as you wish (set Level, other parameters) and click the OK button to save the Project. You can start downloading at any time.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: A missing link when browsing downloaded Web site
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: If you see that a page was not downloaded because of the Project Level or other restrictions, it is easy to add the missing page to the Project and load it immediately

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Loading missing links when browsing a Project offline.

When you finish downloading a Project and you start browsing offline, you may find that not all links were downloaded.

In this case, %OENAME% displays a page with a message that the page cannot be found offline. You may notice two links on the page. One follows the online location of the missing page.

You can drag the online link into the Project in the Projects tree. Drop the link on the Project you are browsing and %OENAME% will offer to create a new Project or to add the link to the existing Project. Select the second option and the link will be downloaded immediately.

You can refresh the page you are browsing and the missing page will be available offline.

The page with the missing page message also contains another link. If you click the link, it will do exactly the same as dragging an online link to the Project. However sometimes the second link is not visible because of narrow frames, etc.

Downloading missing links is supported only in the Pro and Enterprise editions of Offline Explorer.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Mirror sites
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Preventing duplicates when mirror sites are cross linked

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
How to prevent duplicated files on your hard disk when mirror sites are cross linked.

Frequently www.server.com contains absolutely the same information as server.com.

If both sites contain links to each other, you will end with two copies of the same site on you hard disk.

Offline Explorer Pro and Enterprise editions have a new URL Substitutes feature that can greatly help here. You can find it in the Project Properties dialog | Advanced section.

You will need to add a rule to convert one type of link to another. For example, if you are downloading from http://www.server.com, then all links to http://server.com have to be replaced with links to the first server.

This rule is simple (type it in the corresponding fields of the URL Substitutes dialog):

In all URLs http://server.com/* replace http://server.com/ with http://www.server.com/.

Click the Add button below and the OK button to save the rule. Click another OK button to save changes in the Project settings.

Now all links to the mirror site will lead to the starting server automatically.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Removing unwanted links from the Queue
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: How to stop downloading links from the Queue using keywords

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
How to stop downloading links from the Queue using keywords.

You may notice %OENAME% starting to download links that you don't need. For example, you may not need the printer-friendly version of an article. There is an easy way to abort downloading of these links.

First, press the F9 key to suspend the download.

Second, go to the Queue tab, right-click on any URL in the Queue and then click the Select by Mask.... Type the keyword you want to use to select files and click the OK button.

The keyword can be simple, such as:

?printversion=true
or
http://*.adserver.*/*

%OENAME% will select all URLs in the Queue that match the keyword. This may take some time if there are thousands of URLs in the Queue.

Third, right-click any of the selected links (to preserve the selection) and choose Abort.

Fourth, go to the Projects tab, select the Project you are downloading and change its Properties to prevent downloading the links you don't want.

Now you can press F9 again to resume downloading.

You can also use the above to keep the desired URLs and remove all others - just use the Invert Selection feature before aborting them.

The Queue Manager feature is accessible only in the Pro and Enterprise editions of Offline Explorer.

SECTION.TITLE: Converting downloaded sites

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Placing downloaded Web site on a USB key
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Copy downloaded site files on a mobile device to browse it on other computers

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Browsing downloaded Web site on any computer from a mobile memory device.

You can make a Web site viewable offline without any additional software. All you need is a browser (MS Internet Explorer, Netscape, Opera, etc.)

When you finish downloading a site to your hard disk, please select the corresponding Project, go to File | Export in the main menu and export the site to the disk that corresponds to your USB drive (For example, disk G:\ .)

Please make sure you check the "Use Standard extensions for files with known file types" box before you start exporting. You can also check the "Make AutoRun CD" box. If the system supports autorun on the USB drive, the site will be automatically opened when you insert the drive.

If autorun does not work on the USB drive, you can open the contents.htm file on the USB drive to start browsing the site. On most systems it is enough to double-click contents.htm in Windows Explorer when you view the USB drive contents.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Burning a site to a CD disk
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Easy steps to prepare downloaded sites for CD burning

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Burning a Web site to a CD or DVD disc.

%OENAME% doesn't contain CD writing code itself, but it can prepare a downloaded Web site (Project) for easy CD burning.

Most Web sites use very long filenames that are not compatible with the filesystem used on CDs. That's why it is necessary to export a Web site to a CD-compatible format. Export copies to the selected directory of only files that belong to the Project.

Please select the desired Project and select File | Export from the main menu. This will copy the loaded site to some directory which should be later burned to a CD-R or CD-RW disk. In the Export dialog you should select Joliet - CD-R 64 symbols in the Filenames format field and check the Use standard extensions for files with known file types box.

You can also make an AutoRun CD, which will be automatically browsed when you insert the disk. Make sure that the "Create contents file" is checked for easier browsing from the CD.

Now click the Export button and wait until the process completes. Then write the exported directory contents using your favorite CD burning program.

You should calculate the Project files size before exporting it by using the Size button in the Export dialog next to the Browse button.

Most CD-R/RW discs can contain not more than 650 or 700 megabytes of information. Some CD recorders can support larger volumes, but you need to consult your CD recorder manual.

If a Web site's file size is over the available CD disc volume, you can export it to an HTML Help (CHM) file. CHM files compress Web pages, so the same Web site occupies much less space than when using other formats. Thus, a typical CD disc can include over one gigabyte of a compressed Web site.

You can choose HTML Help format in the Put files to field of the Export dialog.

HTML Help files can be browsed on Windows 98/ME/2000/XP and newer systems.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Transferring a downloaded Project to another computer
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Make a compressed Project backup to restore the Project in another copy of the program.

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
%OENAME% can create compressed Project backup files.

Select the desired Project and go to the Tools | Backup/Restore menu. Select Backup Projects.

You will be prompted to type a filename to which to save the Project. All Project backup files have the .boe extension.

Backup files contain Project settings, its Map and all downloaded Web sites that belong to the Project.

You can restore the Project either by double-clicking the .boe file or by selecting it using the Tools | Backup/Restore | Restore Projects menu.

Backup files are also useful if you want to transfer the Project to another computer.

You can backup several Projects or Project Folders at once the same way. Just select the Projects using Shift-click or Ctrl-click before backing them up.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Sending Project settings to a friend
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Share your Project settings without downloaded files with others

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Share your Project settings without downloaded files with others.

If you want to save Project settings in a file, select the desired Project and click the Copy button. Now run Notepad and paste the Project there. Save it to a text file.

Now you can send the text file by E-mail or transfer it to another computer.

To insert the Project into another copy of %OENAME%, open the text file in Notepad, select the whole text and copy it to the clipboard. Then switch to %OENAME% and click the Paste button. The Project will be added to the currently selected folder.

You can transfer several Projects or Project Folders at once the same way. Just select the Projects using Shift-click or Ctrl-click before copying them to clipboard.

SECTION.TITLE: Adding Projects

TUTORIAL.TITLE: How to insert a number of URLs from a text or other file
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Using clipboard for easy Projects creation

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Adding several URLs to %OENAME%.

Adding a set of URLs can be done in few mouse clicks.

If you have them in a text file (one URL per line,) open the file in Notepad or in any other text editor, select all the text and copy it to the clipboard. Now switch to %OENAME% and click the Paste button on the toolbar.

Offline Explorer (standard) can have only one URL per Project, so the program creates a number of new Projects - one per URL inserted.

Offline Explorer Pro and Enterprise editions create one Project with all pasted URLs in it. If you need to create multiple Projects, please hold down the Shift key while clicking the Paste button.

If you want to alter settings in the newly-created Projects, create a new Template File | Templates menu with the desired settings before pasting the URLs. You can choose the Template to apply to new Projects using the drop-down menu on the right side of the Paste button.

Copying URLs from an MS Excel file is also easy. If all URLs are on the same column, select cells with links on the row and click the Copy button on the MS Excel toolbar. Then paste them to %OENAME% the same way as above.

SECTION.TITLE: Solving Problems

TUTORIAL.TITLE: What to do if you loose your Projects
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Restoring Projects file from backup copies

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
What to do if you lose your Projects

In most cases, it is easy to recover lost projects. All Projects are in the webdown.dat file, and there are many backups of that file.

Open the Options dialog | Advanced | File Locations section. Please see the Projects, Maps and Templates folder location.

Now quit %OENAME%, open Windows Explorer and browse to that folder. Select all files with the webdown filename (webdown.dat is the Projects file, the rest are backup copies) and copy them to another directory to keep them intact.

Select the most recent file with the maximum size and copy it back under the webdown.dat filename.

Start %OENAME% to see if all of your Projects are in place. If something is wrong with the Projects list, try to repeat the process with another webdown file.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: How to browse an exported site from a CD under MacOS
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Setting up System 9 and earlier to support Joliet filesystem

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Tuning up MacOS to browse downloaded sites from CDs

The Joliet CD filesystem format is not natively supported under MacOS System 9 and earlier.

Starting with MacOS System X you can seamlessly use CDs burned on other computer systems, such as Windows and Linux.

To enhance System 9 you need to download a system extension to work with Joliet-compatible CDs. The extension is available here:

http://www.tempel.org/joliet/index.html

After this extension is installed everything works the same way as on Windows systems.

TUTORIAL.TITLE: Why URL Filters may stop working?
TUTORIAL.DESCRIPTION: Changing File Filters | Location box setting overrides URL Filters restrictions

SECTION.TUTORIAL:
Why URL Filters may stop working?

The most common reason why URL Filters do not work as expected is an incorrect Location setting. All Project Properties dialog | File Filters categories have a Location box which allows you to overwrite URL Filters restrictions for the given category of files with other settings.

For example, if the Project URL Filters have Load only from the starting server selected, you can still allow File Filters | Images to be loaded from any site by selecting that in its Location box.

Although this brings flexibility to fine-tuning your Project, it can cause confusion.

Please go through all File Filters categories in the Project Properties dialog to see if all of them contain Load using URL Filters settings in their Location boxes. This setting is recommended to prevent loading from all sites.
